title: Apparent weight - connected blocks in free fall

content.question: A block of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> is attached to a block of mass <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math> by a vertical string, as shown. At the instant shown, the blocks are freely falling near the Earthâ€™s surface. Which of the following correctly indicates the acceleration of the block of mass <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math> and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: Equal to <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math>, because the other block is also in free-fall and therefore the tension in the string is zero.
Equal to <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math>, because the force exerted by the string on the bottom block is equal and opposite to the weight of the bottom block.
Less than <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math>, because the string exerts an upward tension force on the bottom block.
Less than <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math>, because the mass of the block is less than the inertial mass of the two-block system.

content.answer: Equal to <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math>, because the other block is also in free-fall and therefore the tension in the string is zero.
